text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon and Daryl Lane. In 1982, science fiction lost one of its most brilliant, innovative, and original writers, Philip K. Dick, dead at 53 of a stroke. Dick left us just as he was finally being discovered by a large number of readers, both science fiction fans and non-fans. Dick had struggled since the early 1950s to write science fiction full-time, and he produced an immense number of novels and stories, including the 1963 Hugo-winning novel The Man in the High Castle. However, for a long time, his fans were a relatively small number of loyal followers. Right. For years, Dick's writing just never really caught on with the majority of science fiction fans. This was especially true in the 50s and early 60s, when fans were more interested in hardware science fiction. But with the social changes of the late 60s and the advent of the new wave, Dick's writing achieved a more deserving status. We talked with a friend of Dick's, Paul Williams, who was known in science fiction for his perceptive portrait of Dick in an article in Rolling Stone. Others will remember Williams as a rock journalist and as the founder of Crawdaddy Magazine. Williams met Dick at the 1968 World Science Fiction Convention in Oakland. They became friends immediately. Williams graciously consented to talking about Dick with us. During most of his writing career, Dick made very little money. We asked Williams why Dick stuck to writing in the face of poor economic returns. I think a real commitment, first of all, to the ultimate, I don't know if I want to say seriousness, but that's really it, a real commitment to what he was creating and what he wanted to say, that always when he's written it's been because he had to write. And it was equally true that it became the only way he could make a living. You know, it's a classic freelance writer situation where even though you're, you know, okay, if you only get $1,500 for a science fiction novel, then what you have to do to stay alive is write six of them in a year, which he came pretty close to doing at one point. But Dick didn't stick strictly to writing science fiction. He wrote mainstream novels as well. It was not until early in the 1960s that he gave up trying to become a successful mainstream writer. And even then, he didn't give up. Although it felt like that to him at the time, he just put it away on the back burner, having tried very, very hard for 10 years. The first 10 years, while he had his first 10 or so science fiction novels published, he wrote a mainstream novel for every science fiction novel he wrote. So really, he was writing two novels for $1,000 advance, one of which would be published in an A-double novel, and the other of which would go from publisher to publisher and just be turned down. And there are still 10 or 11 of those unpublished novels. So there are in existence several manuscripts of mainstream novels written by Dick. We asked Williams if there is any chance these will ever be published. I think that it's inevitable. Bill had mixed opinions about their quality, and I haven't read most of them. But it seems clear, although we may be surprised, that there's nothing as polished or as good as Confessions of the Craft Artist, which I think is actually one of his five or six best books. But because of the interest of Bill's work, it seems inevitable at this point, that one way or another, they will most or probably all be published within the next 10 or 20 years. But probably still by small publishers, not by New York publishers. More about Philip K. Dick with Paul Williams on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Tortoise entrepreneurship society is now offered as小 Tom Okias www.tob spending.org VAU Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane and Bill Vernon. The late Philip K. Dick published some 35 science fiction novels and a few mainstream ones as well. Among Dick's well-known science fiction novels are the Hugo Award winning The Man in the High Castle, Martian Timeslip, The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch, The Androids Dream of Electric Sheep, and Ubik. Dick's career abruptly ended after the publication of three novels very different from all the others, Ballas, The Divine Invasion, and The Transmigration of Timothy Archer. The last one is not science fiction. As Paul Williams told us in our last show, Dick wrote a number of mainstream novels which have yet to be published. Dick's science fiction novels and stories are generally plotted around the character's perceptions of reality. We wondered if Dick were categorized as a science fiction writer simply because there was no other convenient pigeonhole in which to place him. Williams said no. Well, he was truly a science fiction writer and I think that the primary meaning of that is that you belong to the club and you learn by reading science fiction. And he came up writing stories for all the science fiction magazines and then he started writing novels for Don Walheim at A's and was read only by science fiction readers. And was certainly aware of, you know, as a fan, as a reader, all the science fictional plotting devices and the whole, you know, concept of the genre, the sense of, you know, those of us who read science fiction. And I think that's what it means to be a science fiction writer in a lot of ways is to come up from that world and to stay within that world to whatever degree, at least with part of your work. And he definitely did that. He wasn't necessarily satisfied with that. That's easy to understand. But he did, although he was not a great reader of it, after adolescence or whatever, he really loved science fiction. And the people that he wrote for and the people that he communicated with were all pretty much in that world. At least, yeah, I think it diversified more in the last 10 years. But still, I would consider him very squarely a science fiction writer. Williams also told us how Dick felt about his own work. He always had a very kind of self-deprecating or humble attitude towards his work, while at the same time always giving you to know somehow that he really took it as seriously and respected it as much as his most ardent fans. What I'm saying is that he really knew how good it was. But he was able to be very humble about it. The apathetic response of publishers to Dick's experimental mainstream efforts bothered him. What frustrated him, and he was very frustrated by it, was primarily that he didn't have the freedom to write what he called experimental mainstream novels as well. And of course, it was a tremendous victory for him, finally, posthumously, but he was aware of it before he died, when the transmigration of Timothy Archer was published in hardcover to the first publisher that he submitted it to after writing the novel and so forth. Or actually, before writing the novel. So, it was something that he always wanted to do, to write this kind of book. The ghettoization of him, as a science fiction writer, kept in front of us for a long time. More with Paul Williams on his friend Philip K. Dick on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon. And Daryl Lane. Today we're going to look at two of science fiction author Philip K. Dick's best novels, with the help of Paul Williams, who was a close friend of Dick's. The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch and The Man in the High Castle both appeared in the early 60s. It is interesting to note that both made their first appearances in hardcover. That's significant because most of Dick's works first appeared in paperback, 22 novels in fact. It is for this reason that the newly instituted Philip K. Dick Memorial Award honors the year's most original science fiction paperback. The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch details a future in which human colonists on Mars routinely use powerful hallucinogens to relieve the dreariness of their plight, hard work, and loneliness. Then the mysterious Palmer Eldritch appears with a new drug so powerful that its hallucinations totally overcome reality. Many of the passages in the book describe hallucinations and illusions so realistically that the reader might assume Dick had had first that experience. We asked Williams if it is true that Dick had never used hallucinogens before he wrote The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch. We also asked him to comment on the report that in the aftermath of his experiments with psychedelics, Dick was afraid to read the proofs of The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch. It's true that he had never taken LSD or I think any psychedelic drugs before he wrote The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch. He had had experience with amphetamines. And as for then taking LSD and reading The Gallies, that's possibly true, except that it was years before he read The Gallies and maybe years before he took the trip also. But he was afraid of it before he read them. He was, he always claimed anyway, too scared to read The Gallies when they sent them to him. And he didn't finally reread the novel again, according to what he always claimed, until a number of years later. But I'm sure there's no question that it scared him. It scared him while he wrote it. And at one point he told an interviewer that he wrote it to kind of exercise a terrifying vision of the man with the stigmata that he was seeing in the sky while driving to the shack on the California coast that he was doing his writing in. And so again, it was very real to him and terrifying while he was writing in as well as a while reading it. I think, by the way, that it's a brilliant novel. The Man in the High Castle The Man in the High Castle is presently considered to be Dick's major accomplishment. It's an alternate world novel which describes the United States in the aftermath of the Axis powers winning World War II. A sidelight is that characters in the book learn that in an alternate world, the Allies have won. They learn this through the I Ching, the Chinese Book of Changes. It has been reported that for a period, Dick himself consulted the I Ching, but that he repudiated it. We asked Williams if this is true. He did, in several interviews, and he stopped using it. Since I originally was introduced to the I Ching by Phil's book and by someone else who had learned about it from Phil's book, and still use the I Ching, I never took Phil's repudiation very seriously. But he did have the experience that many people have that the book, the oracle eventually told him, you know, to stop. That it wasn't useful for him to keep asking questions of it. And his feeling and what he said was that, you know, it was actually trying to steer him in some wrong fashion. But I think that that kind of incidental effect of the man in the high castle of introducing the Chinese Book of Changes to so many people who then introduced it to the whole culture is very fascinating. We'll talk about Philip K. Dick's last three novels on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane. And Bill Vernon. Science fiction author Philip K. Dick produced a large body of novels and short stories during the nearly 30-year span he wrote. Most of Dick's novels dealt with perceptions of reality, that is, questions such as, what is real? Is that person real or is it a robot? Is this all an illusion? However, the last four novels Dick produced were quite different from his previous efforts. A Scanner Darkly came out in 1977. It's Dick's tribute to all his friends who died from the effects of drugs, and it's a warning to those contemplating their use. Dick's last three novels, Valus, The Divine Invasion, and The Transmigration of Timothy Archer, are related thematically. They all have spiritual, mystical, religious overtones. We wondered if Dick wrote these three novels after undergoing some kind of change of life experience. Here Paul Williams, Dick's friend for many years, comments. It's certainly something new. I mean, he, in fact, saw these three books, these last three books, as a kind of a trilogy, even though they have different settings and subjects. The thematic material is extremely related. And it comes out of his own personal experiences and one sort of mystical experience in particular, and also out of at least six years of really intensive research into theology and philosophy and, in many ways, you know, the spiritual history of human beings, at least over the last 5,000 years or so, which he just totally immersed himself in, originally on the pretext that he was doing research for Valus, which ultimately turned out to be true. But, and there was a period of about three or four years where he didn't write a novel, and we all wondered if, you know, if he would again. And I'm sure he wondered. So that this extraordinary work, particularly the last three books, definitely, as you say, comes from a change of life, so they're not in the sense of, you know, going down to the church and getting religion. Williams then goes on to tell us about the experience, a revelation which awakened it. There was an awakening in him of, brought about as exactly as he describes in Valus, by an incident, I guess, in 1975. where he's sitting in his car in a very Southern California town, Santa Ana, or Fullerton, around there, and is kind of zapped by this pink phosphine light. And nothing was really the same again after that, but, I mean, he spent a couple of hours in a, really, a very subtle kind of other world. And it was only his sense of the importance of this experience that really gives it its way. In other words, exactly what he went through, somebody else might have shrugged off who didn't have his particular powers of perception and interest. That experience is described in Valus, and in slightly different terms in the profile of Dick and Charles Platt's Dream Makers. We asked Williams about the objective reality of Dick's experience. It's a totally subjective experience, you know, even as he describes it, right? It's something that happened to him. That, you know, in fact, one of the issues that comes up for him is how do you prove something like that, you know, to yourself, as much as anyone else. But absolutely no question that it was very real to him, and that, you know, the horse lover fat character in Valus is as real a self-portrait as you could find. So Dick's last three novels, definitely a departure from his previous work, were the result of Dick's own personal experiences. On our next show, we'll take another look at this group of novels. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Science Fiction Radio Show, Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon. And Daryl Lane. Fans of science fiction author Philip K. Dick realized that Dick's last three novels, Valus, The Divine Invasion, and The Transmigration of Timothy Archer, represent a significant departure from his earlier work. As we discussed with Dick's friend Paul Williams on our last show, these novels have a spiritual element which was brought about by a vision Dick experienced in 1975. Only time will tell, but some feel that these three novels, especially The Transmigration of Timothy Archer, will eclipse The Man in the High Castle as Dick's most important work. Valus is Dick's somewhat autobiographical sketch of horse lover fat, and in it are the details of Dick's life-changing spiritual encounter. The Divine Invasion, the most overtly science fictional of the three, is a mystical treatment of the salvation of Earth in the approaching Armageddon. The Transmigration of Timothy Archer is not science fiction. Rather, it's an experimental mainstream novel similar to those Dick tried for years to publish. It's based quite closely on the life of the late Bishop Pike, whom Dick knew for some years. Here Paul Williams tells us a bit of what Dick was driving at in his final three novels. He became obsessed with the revelations that he had around, and his questions about what was that happened to him and why. And ultimately, his answers, which in effect are his answers, and in a sense it's a culmination of his entire work, his answers to tentative or whatever, to all the questions he'd been asking in all his books. What is reality? What is history? What's really going on and why? And what is the real nature of the forces here? And as somebody quoted Einstein as saying, you know, Einstein was asked if he could, a reporter asked him, what would you say if you could have the answer to any question? You know, what question would you ask? And Einstein immediately answered, is the universe friendly? And that was certainly a burning question on the mind of Philip K. Dick in every book he ever wrote. And there is a kind of extraordinary revelation in the last two or three books, in which, while still giving that incredibly penetrating, ruthless vision of the way things really are, and often in still quite a depressing tone, he nevertheless comes through with a very strong conviction that yes, we are ultimately in the hands of, or at least strongly under the influence of, a basically friendly preacher much greater than us that is on our side in a battle that is far from decided. We asked Williams if some of Dick's conclusions might have been based on the tenets of any organized religion. You could make this as similar to the Christian myth, or the myth of almost any other, you know, great world religion, or as different from it as you want it to. You know, you could make a great case that, hey, this man believed, you know, the straight party line, or you could make a great case that he was a heretic whose books should be burned, you know, by every organized and disorganized religion in the world, so that there's no easy conclusion as to, because it is so uniquely his vision, as to what the meaning of the vision and the information part in his last work is. But there seems no question that he begins to really make some very strong statements about what he finally thinks is going on. Philip K. Dick will be sorely missed. He had his ardent fans, and his last three novels will continue to gain him new fans from outside science fiction. We can always hope they'll go back and read his early works. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas.できrennia.com verse 1 Thank you.

Although it felt like that to him at the time, he just put it away on the back burner,

and I haven't read most of them.

Fans of science fiction author Philip K. Dick realized that Dick's last three novels,

represent a significant departure from his earlier work.

these novels have a spiritual element which was brought about by a vision Dick experienced in 1975.

The Divine Invasion, the most overtly science fictional of the three,
